By Ujjwal Narayan
NewsRise
NEW DELHI (Nov 23) -- India’s Supreme Court today adjourned hearing in Future Group’s plea against a lower court order to put on hold the group’s proposed $3.4 billion sale of retail assets to Reliance Industries, amid a dispute with partner Amazon, a lawyer said.

A bench led by Chief Justice NV Ramana heard the plea, and asked counsels of both the parties to make brief submissions during the next hearing on Dec. 8, said the lawyer, who declined to be named.

Billionaire Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries had, last year, agreed to buy the retail, wholesale, warehousing, and logistics businesses of the debt-ridden Future Group. However, the deal has been delayed due to a long-drawn dispute with Amazon.

The dispute started after Amazon sought to block the deal by getting a freeze order from Singapore arbitration court to put the Reliance deal on hold.

Amazon, which had bought a 49% stake in Future Coupons that owns a 7.3% stake in Future Retail, challenged the proposed sale, citing alleged violation of contractual agreements.

Future Coupons moved the Supreme Court, after the Delhi High Court last month rejected its plea seeking a stay on Singapore arbitrator’s ruling.

The deal with Reliance is crucial for Future Group that is on the brink of liquidation.

Future Group and Reliance had, earlier this year, agreed to extend the deadline to complete the merger, to Mar.31, 2022 from September end.

The Supreme Court had, in September, stayed all proceedings in the case, directing authorities such as National Company Law Tribunal, Securities and Exchange Board of India and Competition Commission Of India to not pass any final order related to Future-Reliance deal.

Shares of Future Enterprises gained 5.8% to 8.60 rupees, while those of Future Retail rose 4.6% to 50.20 rupees in Mumbai trading today. The S&P BSE Sensex fell 0.1%.
